summary:
Here is a summary of the document in 3-5 sentences, focusing on the main topic and key concepts:

The Necronomicon, a work attributed to the fictional astronomer, poet, philosopher, and scientist Al-Azrad, has a complex and shrouded history. The text was first translated into Greek by Theodorus Philetas in 950, and later into Latin by Olaus Wormius in 1228. The work was repeatedly translated, printed, and banned throughout the Middle Ages and Renaissance, with various versions emerging, including the Sussex Manuscript and the Voynich Manuscript. Today, only five copies of the Necronomicon are known to exist, although an unknown number may still be held. The text's history is marked by its condemnation by the Church and its association with occult and philosophical circles.

qa_pairs.question: When was al-Azrad born?
qa_pairs.answer: around 700 A.D.

qa_pairs.question: Where did al-Azrad die?
qa_pairs.answer: Damascus

qa_pairs.question: When was the Al Azif translated into Greek?
qa_pairs.answer: in the year 950

qa_pairs.question: By whom was the Al Azif translated into Greek?
qa_pairs.answer: By the Byzantine Theodorus Philetas

qa_pairs.question: When was Philetas' manuscript condemned?
Why was Philetas' manuscript banned in 1232?
qa_pairs.answer: Its rapid circulation among philosophical circles

qa_pairs.question: When was the Latin and Greek versions of the Necronomicon banned by Pope Gregory IX?
When was the first practical printing press using moveable type established?
When is the Greek translation of the Necronomicon likely to have been printed in Italy?
Who was the founder of the Aldine Press, famous for printing unedited Greek and Latin texts?
qa_pairs.answer: Aldus Manutius

qa_pairs.question: When was the first practical printing press using moveable type established?
qa_pairs.answer: The year 1454 saw the first practical printing press using moveable type

qa_pairs.question: Where was a black-letter version of the Latin Necronomicon printed?
qa_pairs.answer: A black-letter version of the Latin Necronomicon had been printed in Germany, probably in Mainz

qa_pairs.question: Who produced an English translation of the Necronomicon in 1586?
qa_pairs.answer: Dr. John Dee produced an English translation of the Necronomicon

qa_pairs.question: From which press is a Greek translation of the Necronomicon believed to have come?
qa_pairs.answer: This version is generally believed to have come from the press of Aldus Manutius

qa_pairs.question: Who was John Dee?
qa_pairs.answer: John Dee, mathematician, astrologer, and physician to Queen Elizabeth of England.

qa_pairs.question: Where was the Greek edition discovered by John Dee?
qa_pairs.answer: Eastern Europe

qa_pairs.question: What was the status of John Dee's translation?
qa_pairs.answer: Never published, but believed to have been made from a Greek edition.

qa_pairs.question: Where was a second printing of the Latin version made?
qa_pairs.answer: Spain, in the early seventeenth century

qa_pairs.question: When was the Latin version of the Necronomicon first printed?
qa_pairs.answer: Early seventeenth century

qa_pairs.question: What is the title of the Sussex Manuscript, also known as the Cultus Maleficarum?
qa_pairs.answer: Sussex Manuscript

qa_pairs.question: When was the Al-Azif—Ye Booke of ye Arab written?
qa_pairs.answer: Late sixteenth century

qa_pairs.question: What is the current location of the Voynich Manuscript?
qa_pairs.answer: University of Pennsylvania

qa_pairs.question: When was the Al-Azif—Ye Booke of ye Arab written?
qa_pairs.answer: The Al-Azif—Ye Booke of ye Arab was written in the late sixteenth century

qa_pairs.question: What is written in the Voynich Manuscript?
qa_pairs.answer: The Voynich Manuscript is written in Greek and Latin using Arab script

qa_pairs.question: What happened to the Necronomicon?
qa_pairs.answer: The Necronomicon was condemned and destroyed by the Church

qa_pairs.question: How many copies of the Necronomicon are known to exist?
qa_pairs.answer: Only five copies of the Necronomicon are known to exist today
